Comments_List: Improved my critical thinking skills; learned about historiography and how to undertake a historiographical project; broadened the scope of my perspective and research interests beyond musicology
I have developed skills for thinking critically about music history, and I come away with many new insights into the various perplexities that are involved in writing about historical events.
This course gave me a very thorough grounding in european theories and philosophies of history from midcentury to around 2000.

The class was quite intense...Overall, I think the intensity could be toned down at times about 1015% without any real consequence. But we learned many things that are applicable to how we approach scholarship, within and outside of music. It's very clear why it's a staple of the curriculum.
Strengths include a good balance between breadth of topics and depth of engagement. I always came away from class meetings with a richer understanding of the material.

I appreciated that we read many texts outside the musical field. I appreciated the challenge of the ideas and topics of the course. The reading list was thorough though at times too demanding. I would skip the Taruskin or do a shorter excerpt.
Yes, though I would give them fair warning.
